audio.def: surgical puncture of the abdomen to remove fluid
moving away from the body midline (the opposite of adduction) (e.g., spreading the arms)
audio.spanishdef: Alejándose de la línea media del cuerpo (lo opuesto a la aducción) (por ejemplo, extendiendo los brazos)

audio.def: outer layers of skin scraped off, resulting in a small amount of sanguineous or serosanguineous drainage, such as a "skinned" knee; open wound resulting in scraping off of skin layer(s) by trauma; may or may not produce bleeding
premature separation of the placenta
one-celled microorganisms; may be found singularly or in chains
an agent or a process that kills bacteria
the science and study of bacteria.
equality between the debit and credit sides of an accounting equation; that which is left over after additions and subtractions have been made to an account; remainder amount due.
a measurement compared with a standard; a method for testing the accuracy of equipment; a quality assurance procedure
unit of energy that produces heat
infection of interconnected group of hair follicles or several furuncles forming a mass.
enlarged heart muscle.
inflammation of a tear sac
digit, finger or toe
a daily record of the services rendered, charges made, and payments received; may be a manual or computerized system
substance that reduces congestion or swelling.

a supplementary classification of ICD-9 coding that denotes the external cause of an injury rather than a disease; explains the mechanism of injury; includes drug events such as poisonings and adverse effects
reflected sound waves used to test the heart for structural or functional abnormalities
toxemia of pregnancy, with high blood pressure, albuminuria, oliguria, seizures, and sometimes coma
characteristic black and blue mark that results from blood as it accumulates under the skin.
oviducts; canals leading from the ovaries to the uterus
greasy material in nutrients transport fat-soluble vitamins, insulate the body from the cold, and provide fatty acids
a list of a physician's customary charges; may incorporate insurance plan-specific discounts
special x-ray technique for examining a body part by immediate projection onto a fluorescent screen.
pear-shaped sac located on the inferior surface of the liver; stores bile to aid in digestion and fat absorption
male(sperm) or female (ovum) reproductive cell
marked swelling of gray matter, located outside the central nervous system, containing cells of neurons
stretching of the stomach
the central processing unit, motherboard, hard drive, disk drive, keyboard, monitor, and mouse of the computer

audio.term: Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA)
audio.def: originally enacted in 1996, contains requirements for patient confidentiality
audio.spanishterm: Ley de Portabilidad y Responsabilidad del Seguro Médico (HIPAA)

audio.def: an association that provides all care to the insured person for a fixed fee, usually paid for by the insured or employer through a monthly premium; a copayment may or may not be required
percentage of red blood cells in the total blood volume
lower portion of the small intestine, opening into the cecum
superior wing-shaped portion of hip bones
the individual's ability to resist specific diseases or disorders, usually by acquiring the corresponding antibody

vaccination; protection from communicable diseases by administration of living attenuated agents (e.g., measles), killed organisms (e.g., pertussis), inactivated toxins (e.g., tetanus), or recombinant DNA (e.g., hepatitis B)

yellow color of skin, white of eyes, and mucous membranes resulting from increased bilirubin in blood; most common causes are obstruction of bile flow, liver dysfunction, and excess destruction of red blood cells
areas where two or more bones come together or articulate
equitable distribution of benefits and burdens
a protein in the epidermis that thickens and waterproofs the skin
two muscular, bean-shaped organs located in the back of the abdominal cavity that filtrate, reabsorb selected substances, and excrete urine
sounds heard through the stethoscope during the measurement of blood pressure; there are five phases
hunchback; an excessive curvature in the thoracic portion of the vertebral column
inner ear; contains vestibule, semicircular canal, and cochlea with receptors for hearing and balance
a jagged traumatic cut resulting in irregular wound edges; straight or jagged cut into the body tissue
a sharp, sterile, disposable instrument used to puncture skin for collecting capillary blood
incision of the abdominal wall
progressive abnormal growth of blood vessels or other structures in the retina, usually leading to blindness
film visualization of internal structures, including soft tissue, by using a magnetic field with radiation
softening of tissue
cancerous.
uncontrollable episodes of falling asleep; also known as sleep epilepsy
pertaining to nose and throat
death of tissue or bone
commission or omission of an act that resulted in or caused harm
20% overweight for sex, height, and type of frame
an ingrown (hidden) nail, finger or toe
lighted instrument used to examine the inner surfaces of the eye.
specialist who can measure for errors of refraction and prescribe lenses but who cannot treat diseases of the eye or perform surgery.
use of fingertips and hands to feel for sizes and positions of specific organs, masses, or other abnormalities; texture and firmness; skin temperature and moisture and flexibility of joints

an endocrine gland located behind the stomach that produces pancreatic juice, which is transported to the duodenum to aid in digestion, and insulin and glucagon, which regulate carbohydrate metabolism
infestation with parasitic lice.
test for cervical cancer that involves microscopically examining cervical scrapings
the identification of a type of pathogen by its appearance in the specimen
the method used to determine the number of bacteria present in a specimen
unit of absorbed dose of radiation
the study of use of radioactive substances to visualize an internal structure
a substance or structure that x-rays will penetrate
substance or structure that is not penetrated by x-rays
an imaginary line or cut through the body, bilaterally separating it into right and left halves
three pairs of glands located in the mouth, secreting saliva that moistens food and begins the chemical breakdown of carbohydrates
knives with various blade shapes and sizes, used to make surgical incisions
software-required device that reads documents (text, graphics, photos) and transfers the image to the computer
increased heart rate (pulse):a heart rate faster than 100 beats per minute
final phase of mitosis; the nucleus divides in the center, forming two distinct cells
a long, two-handled instrument with pointed ends used to grasp tissue during surgery; a cervical tenaculum is commonly used in well-woman exams
connective tissue attaching muscle directly to the periosteum (covering) of the bone
inflammation and ulceration of the mucosa of the colon and rectum
lesions of the mucosa of any organ; most common in the stomach and intestine
medial bone of forearm (in anatomic position)
use of high-frequency ultrasonic waves to produce an image and identify and measure deep body structures and abnormalities
ICD-9 codes identifying health care visits for reasons other than illness
tubule carrying sperm from epididymis to seminal vesicles
male sterilization procedure; tying off or removing part or all of vas defernes
largest body vein, with inferior and superior branches
persons in a disaster who have been triaged at a command center of the community disaster, have minor injuries, and are capable of walking
scheduling a specific number of patients, usually four, at the beginning of the hour
squeaking or whistling breath sound, usually caused by narrowed tracheobronchial airways, as in asthma
medical and disability insurance to cover employees in the event of a work-related injury, illness, or death
